text:
>> Margaret Neale is the Adams Distinguished
Professor Emerita of Management at
Stanford University's

Graduate School of Business. Her teaching and
research focuses on negotiation and decision-making,
collaborations,

the allocation of
burdens and benefits, learning in groups and teams, group decision-making
and diversity.

In a nutshell,
basically everything; she is a professional
of everything. In addition, Professor
Neale has conducted

executive seminars and management development
programs around the world. For those of you that joined
us a couple weeks ago,

we had some technical
difficulties here. We're so happy [LAUGHTER] that you are back with us today.

Maggie, thank you so
much for being here. Please, take it away. It's always a pleasure
to have you with us.

>> Thank you, Robyn, and let me add my
appreciation for those of you who have shown up a second time.

I appreciate the
fact that sometimes the technology is simply
not going to cooperate,
let's hope it does today. Let's talk about negotiation, and one of the biggest hurdles,

especially for women, is that most of us look at
negotiation as a battle.

That battle is characterized by, "I'm going to try
to get stuff from you that you don't
want me to have and

I'm going to try to keep
you from getting my stuff," and if that's how
you think about negotiation,

you're already in
an uphill climb. The reason is because
this negative frame,

this perspective of
battle of negotiation, creates a filter
through which you evaluate your
counterpart's behavior,

and because they are the
other, they are the enemy, they are the people who are keeping you from
getting what you want.

You're going to interpret
their behavior in the most malevolent way possible. In addition, if you think

about having this
battle mentality, it really encourages
you to think about who's going to win and
who's going to lose.
That win-lose perspective creates a pressure for you to try to win,

and sometimes
winning becomes more important than what
it is, you have won.

Now, there are clearly
negotiations that are adversarial, but for you and for me,

most of our opportunities for
negotiation take place with folks with whom we have or

have the potential
for a relationship. What that means is if you think of negotiations as in fight,

you have to pick and choose
your negotiations based upon which counterparts you're

willing to pick a fight with. What I'm going to suggest is
that there's a better way.

First, we'd need to
rethink the definition; to move beyond the simple notion of negotiation is a fight,

to negotiation is a process where two or more
parties decide what each is willing to give and

hopes to get in
their interaction. The next clause is so important.

Through a process of mutual
influence and persuasion, there is no command and
control in negotiation.

I can't force you to say yes, all that I can do is
present proposals, where from your perspective,

in your interest to say yes, and we agree on a common
course of action.

Now, this definition
is very broad and can incorporate all
sorts of interactions.

Some of which are
incredibly adversarial, but some of which are situations where you
might not even think

of them as the possibility
for negotiation. Like, for example, consider

a common experience for me
is my research meetings. When I call my doctoral
students to a research meeting,

the content of that
meeting is about how to create a better research project

and how to move that
project forward. But the context of
that meeting is, which of my scarce
resources will I

contribute to this
particular endeavor and what do I hope to get. They're my students; they

are doing exactly the same thing. Every meeting, in which you
wish to have influence,

is an opportunity
for negotiation. But you're not going
to take advantage of those opportunities

if what you think of
negotiation is a fight. You're going to have
to pick and choose

again who you're
willing to fight with, and simply that's just not
something we want to have as

a characteristic that people think about when
they think about us. What I want you to do is I also

want you to rethink your whole perspective
about negotiation. Move from framing your
negotiations as a battle,

to negotiation as
collaborative problem solving. Now, before you get to

moving much faster
than I am and say, "oh, I already know
what that is," that's a win-win perspective
in negotiation,

unicorns, balloons, and
rainbows everywhere. No. When I talk about
collaborative problem solving,

there are three criteria
that you need to meet. Number 1, to basically
be in a situation where

I as the protagonist
negotiator and better off than my status quo,

better off than my alternatives, better off than had
I not negotiated. Now, while that may seem like
a low bar, I challenge you.

I suspect that all of
you as I have been in negotiation situations where at
the moment before you say yes, you knew should walk away. But you've said yes anyway,

you took an outcome that
made you worse off. First, we need to focus on
what makes us better off.

Number 2, because there is no command and
control in negotiation,

I need to understand
my counterparts, because my counterparts have to voluntarily walk this path
of agreement with me.

I need to understand them. I need to understand
their motives, their preferences, their
interests, and their problems.

Because I've got to be able
to craft a proposal that from their perspective
at least keeps them

whole and perhaps
makes them better off. Otherwise, there's no reason
for them to ever say yes.
Third, and most importantly, when I craft that proposal,

I am going to frame
that proposal as a solution to a problem
that my counterpart has.

You see, too often, we get caught up in a negotiation thinking about
what's in it for me. But because you
need to be so aware

that negotiation is an
interdependent process, my counterpart has to come
with me on this journey.

So I'm going to frame my proposals as a solution
to a problem that they have.

Now this turns out to be
actually a challenge. Why? Because you've
got to be creative in

how you frame and
characterize your proposals. You got to plan and prepare. You got to understand
your counterpart.

The good news is that folks tell you their
problems all the time, and I encourage you to listen

carefully to their
problems and see how creatively you can
frame a solution to

those problems in a proposal that makes you
better off as well.

Now, once you do this, everything can become negotiable because you're no
longer having to

pick and choose your negotiations based upon who you're
willing to fight with. But you've got to be
careful because now,

when so many things become
open to negotiation, you have to be clear about
what you're trying to

achieve in each of
these negotiations. Let me be really clear here,

the goal of a negotiation
is not to get an agreement.

Getting a yes is not the
goal of a negotiation. What I want to highlight is what

researchers have talked about
as the allure of agreement, and so I've got this
graph here, this figure,

and I want you to look at
the relative positions of the orange bar, the orange line,
and the blue line.
In the blue line, this is the result of negotiators

and subjects in the
experiment who were asked to make a choice
between two options,

option A and option B. This is the percentage of
folks who chose option A.

Option A was a
disadvantageous option, not so much so that
nobody chose it.

But you see that depending on
the particular experiment, somewhere between a low of
four percent to a high of

about 35 percent chose option A. The experimenters
then simply changed

the label that they
used in the choice; instead of saying option
A versus option B,

it was the agreement
option versus the no-deal option, same choice.
Look at the orange line, how many more people thought, "hey, this was a good idea."

That space between the
orange and the blue line is really the bias that
we have to agreement.

So when folks say to you, "if you can just make
this concession, we have an agreement."

They have reduced the friction for you to make a concession, and of course, you've
done the same thing.

But I wanted to quantify how powerful that
allure of agreement is, because what you really want

from your negotiation
is a good deal. Now you need to think, "okay, if what I want is a good deal,

then how do I know
what a good deal is?" What I want to suggest to you
is there are, at a minimum,

three components that you need control of before you
begin a negotiation.

The first is, what are
your alternatives, if this deal does not
result in an agreement?

What we're asking here is what happens to you in the
case of an impasse. We're looking here
at alternatives.

How good or poor are your alternatives to this
particular negotiation.

There has been an enormous
amount of research to look at the impact of alternatives
on negotiated performance.

While there's lots of
details in that research, the main finding is
strong and consistent.

She who has the
better alternatives, on average, walks away with
more in the negotiation. Why?

>> The better your alternatives, the easier it is for
you to walk away

or to convince your
counterpart that you will walk away if
you don't want to.

Because if I have a
really good alternative, you're going to have to pay
a premium to me to stay in

this negotiation
because otherwise I can just invoke my alternative. So that's the good news.

Here's the bad news; most of us when we think
about our alternative, we characterize it as,

let's say my alternative is here, if I just exceed
this I'm doing well.

What you have just done by that conjugation is you have just anchored yourself
to your alternative.

It now becomes a standard for acceptability,
acceptable outcomes.

What I want to suggest to
you is that a better way, is to think about your
alternative as a safety net.

and somewhere in
your act something happens and you end
up in the safety net.

This is not an
acceptable performance, you're not happy
with what happened.
But you're in the safety net and because the situation was

resulted in you being
in the safety net, you're really glad it's there. That's how I want you to think
about your alternatives,

it's not a standard
that determines what's acceptable or good enough.

What it is, it is a mechanism that protects you from the
downside, from the fall.

Now, your alternatives are
outside the negotiation, but they affect the
negotiation process itself.
They do so through their impact on your reservation point, your bottom line, your point of

indifference between
the yes and a no. This is arguably the
most strategic piece of

information that you have
in your negotiation. That is, what is the point
at which your negotiation

goes from an outcome that
you could say yes to, to an outcome that
you must say no to.

In fact, if you are negotiating and you're
at your bottom line, another term for your
reservation point.

If you're at your bottom line, you should be so indifferent that you're willing
to flip a coin.

If the coin comes up
heads you walk away, and if it comes up
tails you say, "Yes."

That's how indifferent
you should be. Your reservation point is a bright-line standard
that you do not violate.

How easy that is to say, how hard that is to do. Just what I want to
suggest to you is

that what successful
negotiators do, is they are clear in

understanding that
regardless of how much they want a yes that if
the deal violates

their reservation price
they simply say, "No."

Now, if all you think about is your alternative,
your safety net,

or your reservation point, the worst possible deal
you could say yes to,

you will systematically
underperform in your negotiations. This is a writ large for women.

The reason for that
is because women have lower expectations on average, at least the empirical
research suggests that.

What you need to do is literally leverage up your expectations
about what is possible.

That is through
setting an aspiration, an optimistic
assessment of what you

could achieve in
this negotiation. If you can leverage
up your expectations,

you may not achieve
your aspiration.

But setting an aspiration
will result on average in your walking

away with more in
the negotiation. Because women historically
have had lower expectations,

this is so critical setting
an optimistic assessment.

If this negotiation
went well for me, what could I achieve?

Now, you can have those
three components, but you still got to
decide to negotiate.

I want to highlight the importance of why women need to engage
in negotiations.
One of the most powerful ways I can do that is to describe a study that was done with

184 managers from a very
large organization. They were divided
into two groups,

they were both male
and female managers. They were told that they had a specific amount of money to

allocate to their subordinates who were equally skilled
and responsible, both male and female
subordinates.

There were two conditions.
In the first condition they were told simply, we have this fixed pool of
resources please allocate

these resources to these equally responsible
and skilled employees. In that condition,
there was no difference

in the allocation of
raises to men or women. However, in the second
condition the managers were
told that once they had allocated this fixed pool of money,

that the employees could
come back and ask for an explanation and perhaps

negotiate with them about
the raise they were given. In that condition, both
male and female managers

gave the male
employees two-and-half times the raises they gave
the female employees.

In this case, women were at
disadvantage before they even started negotiating or even
had the opportunity to negotiate. Why this difference? Well,

when the managers
were asked why they did what they did they said, "Look, when we give
women raises they're

not going to complain,
but men will. Men will come into our office but

not all men and not
given every raise, if we give them a high
enough raise a lot of folks will come
to our offices.

So what they'll do is they were very instrumentally
taking money from Jane and giving it to

Bill to keep Bill
out of their office, because they knew Jane
wouldn't negotiate.
Why don't you negotiate?

We don't even think
about it as an option. There are so many situations

where we potentially have the
opportunity to negotiate,

but because we have a motivated misperception that
you can't negotiate here.

I want to dispel that perception, there are so many
situations where people

think you can't negotiate and I just want to suggest
that you have to ask. In fact, one of the things
that I do with my students at

Stanford is in the
first assignment, they have to go out and
negotiate a fixed price item.

They need to bring back proof
and the item that they have purchased that item for
less than the fixed price.

They have to go to Nordstroms, or grocery stores,
or dry cleaners. They have to go to places where

you don't normally negotiate, and bring back proof and
the item that you can.
By the way, when I first gave this assignment about 15 percent think they will be successful,

but about 85 percent are successful at the end
of the assignment.
What I want you to think about is the opportunity to negotiate in

situations where most
folks would say, "You can't negotiate here." I would challenge you try.

>> But there's a
big other group of situations where people know
other people negotiate.

Let's say, for example,
you're being made a job offer or you're
being offered a promotion,
and you say to yourself, "I know other people negotiate. But I'm concerned about

the adversarial nature
of negotiation, I don't want to get a
reputation for being greedy, or demanding, or not nice.

Here's what I'm going to do. I'm going to take that job or I'm going to take
that promotion,

and I'm going do
really good work. Then when my employer
sees my really good work,

then I'll get what I deserve." Have those thoughts ever
run through your mind?

If they have, how did
it work out for you? Well, I can tell you that for me,

I'm pretty sure my dean likes me, and when I do good stuff for the graduate school of
business at Stanford,

I'm pretty sure he's pleased
that I'm a faculty member. But I can also assure you, that when I do really good
stuff for the school,

he doesn't think, "I'm wondering if we're
paying her enough." This doesn't cross his mind.

Let's talk about the
choice to negotiate. The way I want to do this,

is I want to highlight a piece of research you may
have heard about. Linda Babcock is the
co-author of a book called,

Women Don't Ask: Negotiation
and the Gender Divide. What led her to
write that book was
her stint as an Associate Dean at Carnegie Mellon University. She was a negotiation researcher.

As associate dean, she
did what we all do, and that is we send out

exit interviews to the
MBAs as they leave. One of the questions was, what's your starting salary
in your new position?

What she found was
the starting salaries of men were 7.6 percent higher than those of the women

graduating same
year, same degree. Now, there's a lot of reasons
why this could happen,

but it turns out that because Linda was a negotiation
researcher, she asked a second
set of questions.

She said was, when
you got your offer, did you attempt to negotiate the terms of your
employment contract?

What she found was that only
seven percent of the women, while over half of the men

attempted to negotiate
for more money. She also found something, she said, "How
successful were you?"

She found no
difference by gender. Everybody who
negotiated, on average,

got about seven-and-a-half
percent increase in their salaries.

At this point, I think
it's interesting for us to talk about the
cost of not negotiating.

The way I'm going to do that, is I want to do that through
a thought experiment.

I want you to engage with me
in this thought experiment. Suppose at age 30,

two equally qualified
applicants, Chris and Fraser, get job offers for
$100,000 a year,

and they're working
for the same company. Now, Chris negotiates.

Now, let's say Chris gets
an increase of 7.6 percent. Chris starts out at 176,

Fraser accepts the $100,000, and now we're going to make
two heroic assumption.

Number 1, they stay at the same company for
the next 35 years so we can see what happens.

Number 2, the company treats Chris and
Fraser identically,

they give Chris and Fraser the same five percent
raises annually.

Now, Chris retired at age 65. The question I need
to ask you is,

how much longer do you think
that Fraser will have to work until Fraser makes

as much money as Chris did
when Chris retired at 65? I just want you to think.
All we're saying is,

how much did that decision
35 years ago cost Fraser in terms of
additional years of work?

I guess I'm wondering, would you be surprised if
the answer were seven years?

In order for Fraser
to make as much money as Chris did in 35 years,
Fraser has to work 42 years.

Maybe that negotiation thing may be important to
pay attention to. But it gets worse,

because this was a very conservative estimate
of the difference. Because, what happens if
you think about this,

over the course of those 35 years while their salary
started off very close, 176 and 100,000, all
over those 35 years,

the difference between
their salaries now, at 35th year is more than
$100,000 a year different.

How does the company interpret
that salary difference?

Well, they're probably
going to say, Chris is more important, we pay Chris more.

Nobody is going to say,
you remember 35 years ago, Chris negotiated
and Fraser didn't.

Nobody is even around who still believes
and remembers that. Now, you can be alive.

Let's say that Chris gets five-and-a-half percent
over those 35 years,

while Fraser gets five percent. You wouldn't even notice that
difference on a year basis.

But over 35 years, how much longer will
Fraser have to work now?

Eighteen years longer. I'm going to do one more
and then we'll stop.
What if Chris got six percent as a raise

every year and Fraser
got five percent? Now, how many more years?

Forty seven. Fraser
can't live long enough.

Because Fraser has got to
be over 100 [LAUGHTER] before Fraser will earn an
equivalent amount of money.

The cost of not successfully negotiating one's starting salary could be addition
7-47 years of work.

Yes, this is an extreme
and hyperbolic statement. I want this to be
embedded in your minds.

If you do the math, and you realize I still want to negotiate,
given the cost,

then I hope you like your job, because you'll be working
there for a lot longer, for a lot less.

Let's talk a little bit more
about why women don't ask, and there is a
significant amount of

research that gives
us some insight. When we negotiate a
single issue like salary,

women are less likely
to negotiate than men. But it's for a good reason.

It turns out that evaluators
penalize female candidates

for asking for a raise in ways they don't penalize
male counterparts.

Particularly, male
evaluators penalize females for asking for more,

while not penalizing
their male counterparts. Now, there's a little bit of
good news in a weird way.
Female evaluators penalize both male and female candidates

for asking for a raise. At least the playing
field's level, it's still not good.
Why do they do that? It's the perception of not being nice and being too demanding,

that explains the backlash. Part of what I also want
to highlight is it's not

just the penalties
that women experience, it's a combination of
the penalties with

the low expectations that they will actually achieve
their outcome. You bring those two
together and it's clear why

women are more
hesitant to negotiate.

>> We also have
done some research recently to try to understand
this a little better.

It's a little bit different because part of the world
we're trying to figure out is, is it the case that women are

too nice when they negotiate? That is, they aren't
pushing hard enough, or are they getting a backlash when they
try to negotiate?

We have two competing hypothesis. Women aren't
sufficiently assertive. That's the tameness account.

Or that women are fine in
terms of assertiveness, but they get backlash.

So we basically collected
data for five years, got 2500 individuals who were in

executive education
programs from around the world and what we found

was a very interesting effect. What we found first, was that there was
no difference in

negotiation
performance by gender. So the notion of women
not asking wasn't really

a possibility here because
everybody in this data-set, were all in a situation

where they knew they
were going to negotiate. So this difference
between the propensity of women not to ask
and for men to ask,

is going to be mitigated here. But we found a very
interesting finding.

That was, when women
had good alternatives, so in this situation,

negotiators could have
good alternatives or poor alternatives, and of course that means they
were facing counterparts

both male and female who had
good or poor alternatives. What we found was,

is that when female negotiators
had good alternatives and we're facing counterparts
with good alternatives.

That is two equally
powerful players. Women were six times
more likely to reach

an impasse with their
counterparts male or female, it were a male with
a good alternative.
This finding strongly supports the backlash account because

what we find is and we
can see it in this graph, basically, we have a
strong alternative

and males actually
got a whole lot more. When you see the dark box here,

this is a female with
a strong alternative. You see that in fact, they got significantly less

and that was whether we included the impulses or we
excluded the impulses, the effect remains the same.

So one of the challenges is, is that when women act
assertively in negotiation,

there is push-back from their male and
female counterparts. So what I want to
suggest to you is,

we need to think differently
about how we negotiate. What I would like the world
to be is that there would be

a level playing field
and I wouldn't have to basically say to women, you have to behave differently
in order to be successful.

But in this case, there continues to be evidence that the
playing field is not

level and so women have to behave differently in order to get
more of what they want. [NOISE] So what has to happen?
Women have to act differently. They have to ask differently.

It turns out, this research has been going on for
quite a long time,

that women are going
to be much more effective if they pair their ask with a communal
concern for the other.

Now what do I mean
by communal concern? Well, it turns out that's

a collaborative
problem-solving approach. How can my ask help you achieve the goals
that you want to achieve?

You see, this is so important because if women simply
asked for themselves,

they get pushed back. So if what we can do is
we can couch or ask in

a solution that helps my
counterpart and make it clear how that solution does solve
problems of my counterpart.

We change the nature
of the conversation. No longer is this a battle.

Now, we're simply trying to
find solutions to problems.

So what I want to highlight
is the power of the ask.

If you don't ask
for what you want, how will others know
what it is you want?

One of the ways that I
want to highlight this is, that I want to give you

a really bad news,
good news perspective.

So it turns out that when
women ask for themselves,

they typically get less than
their male counterparts. This is equating everything.
Same vedas, same person, but just a male versus a female.

Same verb, same words. Women will get pushed
back where men

don't when they're
asking for themselves. But when asking for others,

women are more
successful negotiators than their male counterparts.

In fact, when asking for others, women outperform
men 14-22 percent.
This is a huge difference.

Because what this says is, and this is a very
important data point.

Because what this says is, it's not that women
can't negotiate, is that when we do negotiate

and ask for assertively
what we want, we find ourselves in
a backlash situation.

But when we ask for others,
there's no backlash. I don't get accused of being
greedy or demanding or not
nice when I'm negotiating for my organization or for my team. Where I get those accusations

is when I negotiate for myself. This is why the
problem-solving perspective

is so important. Remember that first criteria, I need to be better
off in my status quo,

better off in my alternatives, better of had I not negotiated, but I couple that
aspiration with trying to

propose or framing a proposal as a solution to a problem
that my counterpart
has and all of a sudden, the conversation is different.

I want to highlight
the power of the ask. Because if you don't
ask for what you want,

you may have to be clever
in how you do that, but if you don't ask for
what you want, who will.

What I want to do is, I want to say a
couple of things in closing before we open
this up for questions.

One of the biggest challenges that I think women face not when they're just negotiating
but in the world,

is the competence versus
likability paradox.

It turns out that men can
be competent and likable.

But women are often
faced with the choice whether to appear competent
or to appear likable.

That is, competent women
are often perceived as not likable and likable women are
not perceived as competent.

So the question that I would
like to have you consider,

and I think this is not
something that can be answered in the moment. It has to be something
that is answered over time and again and again.

How much are you willing to pay to potentially
be perceived as nice and to avoid the
discomfort of asking?

Why I want to
highlight this notion of potentially be
perceived as nice. Because as you are
more successful,

as you move up in
your organization, as you take on leadership roles,

there are going to be people
who do not like what you do and we all want to be liked.

There is a tendency
if we have to choose, sometimes we choose
likability over competence.

But what I want to suggest to you is that you may
want to think about disentangling the
situations where you are

competent and where likability
is really important.

What I want to suggest if
likability is important, and by the way, it is important.

I want people to like me. But I also know that
sometimes I have to make

tough decisions in my
role as a faculty member, in my role as an administrator,
in my role as a mentor, that makes people unhappy and they find that I'm not

particularly likable
in the moment. Well, what I've
learned over time,

if I could come
home after work and my husband will say to me something like,
how was your day?

I'll tell him and then he'll
go on about his business. But I have three dogs.

When I come home from work, whether I've been
gone on a trip and I've been gone for a week or I

have just gone to the grocery store and I've
been gone for an hour, they're like, "Oh,
my God you're back.

It's so wonderful. We thought you were gone
forever and our life was so sad and lonely and
dark without you.

We're so glad you're here." You see, if you really
want to be liked, I have a solution.

Get a dog or better yet, get a rescue and save two lives because they will
love you unconditionally.

That's where you can get
your likability needs met. At work, I'm not saying
don't be likable,

don't be personable, but don't sacrifice competence
for likability.

We need to be strategic
in how you ask. I'm encouraging you to embrace

that collaborative
problem-solving perspective. I cannot overstate how
important that is.

You see, you can think about
it from my perspective. I do research in negotiation.

I teach negotiation, I
write books in negotiation. So my colleagues and I have
been an Associate Dean.

When I get into a room with my colleagues,
they're like, "Oh, you're negotiating" and they start putting on
that battle armor,

getting ready for a fight. I'm like, no. I might negotiate with people
out there but with you,
we're going to problem-solve. It diffuses the situation,

it changes the conversation. I want to encourage
you to embrace
